author: By Maya King
title: In Georgia, Trump Tries to Revive a Sputtering Campaign
description: The former president held a rally in rural Georgia on Saturday in an attempt to jump-start David Perdue’s campaign to unseat Gov. Brian Kemp.
content: COMMERCE, Ga., — When Donald Trump recruited David Perdue to run for governor of Georgia, Mr. Trump’s allies boasted that his endorsement alone would shoot Mr. Perdue ahead of the incumbent Republican governor, Brian Kemp. Georgia Republicans braced for an epic clash, fueled by the former president’s personal vendetta against Mr. Kemp, that would divide the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Neighbor’s Aboveground Pool Is Filthy. What Can I Do?
description: Neglected pools can attract mosquitoes and are an eyesore. But tread carefully as you try to convince a pool owner to improve conditions.
content: Q: Last year, my husband and I bought a condo in a duplex building in Jersey City, after living in New York City for 32 years. Our rear windows overlook our neighbor’s backyard, which has an aboveground pool filled with filthy water. When we arrived last August, the pool was bright blue and inviting. But now the water is a stagnant eyesore. We are concerned, as are our downstairs neighbors, that mosquitoes are breeding there. With summer approaching, we would love for the pool to be cleaned. But how should we proceed? Is it pushy to approach the owners? Is there an agency we could call to intervene?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Michael Levenson
title: In a Fiery Speech, Biden Warns of a Battle Between ‘Liberty and Repression’
description: The president warned Western nations that the fight against autocracy would be costly and could be lengthy.
content: WARSAW — President Biden delivered a forceful denunciation of Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine on Saturday, declaring “for God’s sake, this man cannot remain in power,” as he cast the war as the latest front in a decades-long battle between the forces of democracy and oppression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Streaming Took Over Hollywood. Will It Take Best Picture, Too?
description: A few years ago, the entertainment industry was arguing over whether movies on streaming services even counted as a film. Now, one is poised to win the Oscars’ top prize.
content: Three years ago, Hollywood was engaged in a knock-down, drag-out fight over the future of cinema — what, exactly, constitutes a film — with the Oscars as the boxing ring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: New York’s mayor faces a backlash over a vaccine exemption for athletes.
description: Since lifting the private employer vaccine requirement for professional athletes and performers based in New York City on Thursday, Mayor Eric Adams has drawn the ire of city employees, their unions and others who still must adhere to the mandate or lose their jobs.
content: Since lifting the private employer vaccine requirement for professional athletes and performers based in New York City on Thursday, Mayor Eric Adams has drawn the ire of city employees, their unions and others who still must adhere to the mandate or lose their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: China Confirms All 132 People on China Eastern Plane Died in Crash
description: Investigators were still looking for wreckage, remains and the second black box in an effort to determine what caused the crash.
content: Chinese authorities officially confirmed Saturday that there were no survivors in the crash of a China Eastern 737-800 earlier this week with 132 people on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Nebraska Congressman to Resign After Being Found Guilty of Lying to F.B.I.
description: Representative Jeff Fortenberry announced he would leave his seat at the end of the month, just days after he was convicted on charges of lying to investigators about an illegal campaign donation.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Jeff Fortenberry, Republican of Nebraska, announced on Saturday that he would resign from Congress at the end of the month, days after he was convicted on charges that he lied to federal authorities about an illegal campaign donation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Ashley Southall
title: As Adams Toughens on Crime, Some Fear a Return to ’90s Era Policing
description: With violent crime surging, Mayor Eric Adams is testing how much policing a changed New York City will tolerate.
content: In Mayor Eric Adams’s first three months in office, New York City has been marred by shootings and hate crimes, a fatal subway shoving in Times Square and other high-profile killings. Now, the mayor is testing just how much a liberal city is willing to empower its police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Kevin Draper
title: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament: N.C. State Somehow Escapes Notre Dame
description: Raina Perez hit a late layup to give North Carolina State a win. Michigan got past South Dakota. Louisville and UConn advanced with much more ease.
content: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Raina Perez, a North Carolina State guard, charged toward the basket and glanced behind her, her eyes searching for the kind of Saturday afternoon chaos she had just started back at midcourt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Dirck Halstead, Photojournalist Who Captured History, Dies at 85
description: Shooting for Time magazine and United Press International, he documented presidents, the Vietnam War and more.
content: Dirck Halstead, who photographed world-shaking events for half a century for United Press International, Time magazine and other news outlets, sometimes under harrowing conditions, died on Friday in Boquete, Panama. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Biden Administration Plans to Offer Second Booster Shots to Those 50 and Up
description: After fraught discussions, officials decided that another shot might save thousands of lives if a new coronavirus wave hit before the fall. The F.D.A. could authorize the boosters next week.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is planning to give Americans age 50 or older the option of a second booster of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna coronavirus vaccine without recommending outright that they get one, according to several people familiar with the plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How to Watch the Oscars 2022
description: A guide to everything you need to know for the 94th annual Academy Awards on Sunday night.
content: The 94th annual Academy Awards haven’t even gotten started yet, and there’s already drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: After meeting with Ukraine refugees, Biden calls Putin ‘a butcher.’
description: His comment came as he visited a stadium in Warsaw where the Polish authorities are assisting the waves of people who are fleeing Ukraine.
content: WARSAW — President Biden called President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia “a butcher” on Saturday, in response to a question after meeting with Ukrainian refugees in Warsaw, including several from Mariupol, the city that has been flattened by days of shelling from Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At the Edge of Kyiv, Ukrainians Show Off Their Counteroffensive
description: Destroyed tanks and body parts are all that are left of a Russian advance, part of the larger battle to block the invaders’ attempt to enter or encircle the capital.
content: NORTHERN OUTSKIRTS OF KYIV, Ukraine — When Ukrainian forces hit a Russian tank with an American-made Javelin missile on a highway on the northern reaches of the capital, Kyiv, the explosion was so huge that it tossed the turret 10 yards down the road and shredded the rest of the vehicle and the men inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Addressing Qatar, Zelensky urges energy producers to increase their exports to Europe.
description: “The future of Europe rests with your efforts,” Ukraine’s leader said in a plea to help the continent wean itself off Russian fossil fuels.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, speaking by video to a major policy conference in Qatar on Saturday, urged that nation and other energy producers to increase their gas exports to Europe as part of a drive to reduce the continent’s reliance on Russian fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Margaret Atwood on National Myths and the Roots of Totalitarianism
description: The Canadian author, whose dystopian novels fit with how many people feel about this moment, spoke on “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Margaret Atwood always brushes aside suggestions that her dystopian novels are prescient. But in recent years, it has become difficult to see them as anything but that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glynnis MacNicol
title: It’s a Dog’s Life, if You Want It
description: As travel returns, so are requests for dog sitting — after all, those pandemic puppies aren’t taking care of themselves.
content: For much of my 20s, my knowledge of life in New York City, often in neighborhoods I could never hope to afford, was in part the result of my willingness to care for other people’s dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caryn Ganz and Joe Coscarelli
title: Taylor Hawkins, Foo Fighters’ Drummer, Dies at 50
description: Hard-hitting and charismatic, he was direct about his hopes for the group’s future, even after two decades. “I want to be the biggest band in the world,” he said.
content: Taylor Hawkins, the hard-hitting, charismatic drummer for Foo Fighters, the enduring Rock & Roll Hall of Fame band that has won 12 Grammys and released seven platinum albums, has died at 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Federal Covid Cash Kept New York State Afloat. That Could End Soon.
description: An influx of federal funds may have saved the M.T.A. and staved off painful budget cuts in Albany and New York City. There’s a fight over what comes next.
content: Year after year, no matter the president or the strength of the economy, New York’s fiscal relationship with Washington almost always follows the same pattern: The state gives more to the federal government — sometimes billions more — than it gets back in federal spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: A Minnesota man is released after being held by Russian troops for 10 days.
description: Tyler Jacob was taken off a bus by Russian soldiers at a checkpoint in Crimea, his mother said. He had been teaching English in the Ukrainian city of Kherson.
content: A man from Minnesota who was detained by Russian troops as he tried to leave Ukraine has been released, according to his family and a United States senator from his home state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Spreadsheets, Interplanetary Travel and Housekeeping
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republican Senators Play the QAnon Game
description: On the dishonest questioning during Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation hearings.
content: Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee have spent the last week smearing Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, President Biden’s nominee for the Supreme Court, as indifferent to (and soft on) child sexual abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For Ukrainians, Social Media Is a Powerful Place to Fight Russians
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 26, 2022.
content: “A neighbor said that God left Mariupol. He was afraid of everything he saw.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: A history of the tensions between Ukraine and Russia.
description: Here is a look at some key events in the run-up to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Two former republics of the Soviet Union — Russia and Ukraine — are once again in conflict. Here are some pivotal moments in the years leading up to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24, as well as a brief look at their relationship in the 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Predictable Story Lines Don’t Show Up to Play in the N.C.A.A. Tournaments
description: The fun of March Madness lies in swatting away expected narratives like a lazy layup.
content: The second-seeded Iowa Hawkeyes entered the second round of the women’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament heavily favored to win over the Creighton Bluejays. Iowa had the best player on the court: the point guard Caitlin Clark, who led the country in points and assists. Iowa had the home-court advantage, with nearly 15,000 fans in attendance expecting to see an Iowa victory that would take the Hawkeyes to the Sweet 16.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Mideast Feels the Pinch of Rising Food Prices as Ramadan Nears
description: Russia’s war on Ukraine has driven up the prices of staple foods and energy across the Middle East and North Africa ahead of the Muslim holy month of daytime fasting and nighttime feasting.
content: CAIRO — The price of groceries was going up everywhere Souad Amer checked, so it was with nervous hope that she waded into a government-subsidized market in her Cairo neighborhood where a loudspeaker blared a jingle promising cheap essentials for Ramadan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Afghan Refugees in U.K. Are Still in Limbo as Ukrainians Arrive
description: Some 12,000 Afghans who fled to Britain have been living in hotels for months awaiting permanent housing. This has raised questions about the country’s ability to take in many more escaping Ukraine.
content: LONDON — A toddler cries on his mother’s lap while his twin naps a few feet away. The mother hushes their older siblings, who are watching videos on an iPad in the next room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden denounces Russian invasion, casting it as part of a decades-long attempt to crush democracies.
description: Speaking in Warsaw, President Biden described Vladimir V. Putin as a tyrant with “a craving for absolute power and control.”
content: WARSAW — President Biden delivered a forceful denunciation of Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine on Saturday, declaring “for God’s sake, this man cannot remain in power” and casting the military clash in Europe as the “test of all time” in a decades-long battle to defend democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: In Difficult Cases, ‘Families Cannot Manage Death at Home’
description: Health care researchers argue that hospice facilities could better serve some terminal patients, and ease the burden on exhausted loved ones.
content: Where do people most want to be when they die? At home, they tell researchers — in familiar surroundings, in comfort, with the people they love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
title: Biden’s Barbed Remark About Putin: A Slip or a Veiled Threat?
description: The conclusion of Mr. Biden’s speech on Saturday was a reminder of how precarious diplomacy can be when bombs are already dropping.
content: WARSAW — They were among the final few words of a carefully crafted speech. But they strayed far from the delicate balance that President Biden had tried to strike during three days of wartime diplomacy in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rising Fares, Low-Cost Airlines: Navigating the New Reality in the Sky
description: A post-Omicron travel boom has encountered headwinds from fuel costs and the war in Ukraine. Here’s how changes in the airline industry could affect the cost of your next trip.
content: Leisure travel is back after the Omicron wave, with travel off only about 8 percent last weekend compared to the same period in 2019, according to the Transportation Security Administration’s checkpoint numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: These Artists’ Hunt for Studio Space Ended at the World Trade Center
description: Silver Art Projects, in its third year at 4 World Trade Center, is one of the programs that provide emerging New York artists with free studio space. Now it is adding an executive director.
content: On the 28th floor of 4 World Trade Center, Tourmaline, a multidisciplinary artist, works from a corner studio that features two walls of windows and a view of the 9/11 Memorial. Next door, another artist, Tariku Shiferaw, has his own space to paint and create installation art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Colorado Jury Awards $14 Million to Demonstrators Injured in George Floyd Protests
description: Jurors in the civil case found that the Denver Police used excessive force against the 12 plaintiffs.
content: Jurors in Colorado on Friday ordered the city and county of Denver to pay $14 million in damages to 12 plaintiffs after finding that police officers used excessive force against them during demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Mired
description: Ashton Anderson and James Mulhern team up to surprise us with a gnarly Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I imagine that the two constructors of today’s puzzle broke into sly smiles like the above alligator’s on more than one occasion while devising this obstacle course. The constructors, Ashton Anderson and James Mulhern, have conspired before, on a Friday grid in 2017. (That one has some similarities to today’s themeless, including a “name that tune” clue.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Ron Lieber
title: Trade Your Crypto. Buy Your NFTs. And Pay Your Taxes.
description: The question about whether you made money on cryptocurrency is even higher on your tax form than the line for your wages. There are new tools to help you get it right.
content: The Internal Revenue Service may run on ancient technology, but that isn’t stopping it from taking its cut from your newfangled cryptocurrency winnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament: What to Watch as the Round of 8 Begins
description: After upsetting the No. 1 seeds Gonzaga and Arizona, Arkansas and Houston are looking for more. Duke and Villanova stand in their way.
content: On Saturday, two teams will book spots in the Final Four of the men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament in New Orleans, while two others will see their seasons come to end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Arizona Offers Driver’s Licenses on iPhones. Other States Want to Be Next.
description: Digital copies of licenses and state-issued IDs, which can also be stored on Apple Watches, will only work at security checkpoints at a Phoenix airport for now, officials said.
content: It started as a digital catchall for credit cards and concert tickets, enabling anyone with an iPhone to be waved through checkout lines and turnstiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Where to Enjoy New York City’s Cherry Blossoms
description: Though the earliest cherry trees have already begun blooming, there are weeks of pink and white flowers ahead.
content: After months of dreary weather and bare branches, it’s finally cherry blossom season in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: You Don’t Know Much About Jay Penske. And He’s Fine With That.
description: A quiet Hollywood power broker with a famous name goes on a buying spree that has given him Rolling Stone, South by Southwest and a private island. What more does he want?
content: For the media executive Jay Penske, awards season is money season. It’s the time of year when Disney and Netflix, along with the other studios and streamers, demonstrate their love for the talent by spending millions on For Your Consideration ads in Variety, The Hollywood Reporter and Deadline, as well as the niche outlets Gold Derby, IndieWire and TVLine. All of those publications, which cover things of special interest to Oscar and Emmy voters, are part of Penske Media Corporation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Getting Covid Shots in the Littlest Arms Might Not Be That Easy
description: Authorization is one step; it’ll take time to resolve confusion and hesitancy.
content: Amid the monthslong roller coaster of updates about the efficacy and anticipated availability of a Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine for younger children, we have a new development: Moderna announced this week that it will submit the results of a two-dose vaccine trial for children ages 6 months to under 6 years for Food and Drug Administration emergency use authorization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Public Health Catastrophe Looms in Ukraine, Experts Warn
description: Even before the war, the country struggled with epidemics of H.I.V., tuberculosis and hepatitis. The conflict threatens to undo decades of progress.
content: A convoy of five vans snaked slowly on Friday from the battered Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, toward Chernihiv, in the northeast of the country. On board were generators, clothes, fuel — and medications needed to treat H.I.V.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: I’m Still Standing
description: August Lee-Kovach delivers a challenge from antiquity.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid is built on an exuberant historical theme, and it delights me that it sprang from the mind of August Lee-Kovach. August is making his Sunday debut as the youngest constructor of a Sunday Times puzzle, at the age of 14 years 11 months. He is a freshman at Concord-Carlisle High School in Concord, Mass., and started solving crosswords with his family at age 9. (Someone would read clues aloud, and anyone could call out answers.) This is his third puzzle for The Times since last October, when he started his run with an excellent Saturday crossword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: The Making of Vladimir Putin
description: The 22-year arc of the Russian president’s exercise of power is a study in audacity.
content: PARIS — Speaking in what he called “the language of Goethe, Schiller and Kant,” picked up during his time as a K.G.B. officer in Dresden, President Vladimir V. Putin addressed the German Parliament on Sept. 25, 2001. “Russia is a friendly European nation,” he declared. “Stable peace on the continent is a paramount goal for our nation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Lee E. Koppelman, Trailblazing Long Island Planner, Dies at 94
description: He was a pioneer in grappling with suburban sprawl and preserving open spaces, helping to shape the region.
content: Lee E. Koppelman, a planning visionary who during four decades fought to impose a regional agenda for economic development and environmental conservation across Long Island, died on Monday in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Jo Becker and Alan Feuer
title: Texts Show Ginni Thomas’s Embrace of Conspiracy Theories
description: In the aftermath of the 2020 presidential election, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas was involved in a range of efforts to keep President Donald J. Trump in power.
content: Two days after the 2020 election, Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, texted an old friend, Mark Meadows, the chief of staff to President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden to Include Minimum Tax on Billionaires in Budget Proposal
description: The tax would require that American households worth more than $100 million pay a rate of at least 20 percent on their income as well as unrealized gains in the value of liquid assets like stocks.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House will ask Congress on Monday to pass a new minimum tax on billionaires as part of a budget proposal intended to revitalize President Biden’s domestic agenda and reduce the deficit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: The Biden administration plans to offer a second booster shot to older Americans.
description: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is planning to give Americans age 50 or older the option of a second booster of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna coronavirus vaccine without recommending outright that they get one, according to several people familiar with the plan.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is planning to give Americans age 50 or older the option of a second booster of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna coronavirus vaccine without recommending outright that they get one, according to several people familiar with the plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Tanya’s Sister Was Trapped in Mariupol. This Is Their Story.
description: The generational struggle at the heart of the war in Ukraine.
content: KORCZOWA, Poland — On the second day of the war, Tanya quit her job as a tax accountant in Massachusetts and told her husband that she had to go home to Ukraine. Her sister and her sister’s two teenage sons were holed up in the bathroom of their home in Mariupol, a seaside city that was getting shelled. Tanya got a text from her: “We’re so scared.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: An Oscars Preview
description: The 94th Academy Awards are tomorrow night. We have a guide.
content: I’m excited for the Oscars in a way I haven’t been in a while. I’ll admit to not having seen every nominated film (we still have time to cram!) but no matter. I’ll tune in to see whether three hosts are better than none, whether Lin-Manuel Miranda scores an EGOT and to see Beyoncé perform.  I’ll watch for the fancy clothes, for the swelling music and clip montages, the presenters’ banter and the teary acceptance speeches. I’m tuning in for the pageantry of it all. If you’re with me, here’s everything you need to know to prepare for the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Paying Taxes in 2022: What You Need to Know
description: Did you make money on GameStop? Miss a stimulus payment? Have a student loan forgiven? Let our guide fill you in.
content: Last year may have felt like nothing more than an extension of 2020 — a slog of Zoom meetings, testing lines and will-we-or-won’t-we return to office plans. But 2021, the first full year of the pandemic, may look different when it comes to your taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Feeding my desperate need to make words, one point at a time.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Summit Shows Ties With Arabs Moving From Ceremony to Substance
description: Four Arab foreign ministers will meet in Israel’s Negev desert on Sunday, along with their U.S. counterpart. The talks mark a realignment of Middle Eastern powers, accelerated by the war in Ukraine.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s meeting with top diplomats from four Arab countries and the United States, set to start on Sunday, is one of the strongest signs yet that the country is beginning to reap the dividends of normalization deals reached two years ago, a profound realignment of Middle Eastern powers that has been accelerated by the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: A Police Shooting in West Texas and a Mother’s Search for Answers
description: More than three weeks after her 14-year-old son was shot to death, Dora Vela is still trying to learn the basic facts of the case.
content: On the afternoon of March 3, Dora Vela was in the middle of her shift as a mail carrier when a message on her phone popped up with news about her 14-year-old son. Ms. Vela immediately called back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Lieberman
title: A Young Parisian Chef with a Theatrical Flair
description: Julien Sebbag, a self-taught chef and caterer, has turned his cheeky Instagram videos into high-profile restaurant stints.
content: Name: Julien Sebbag
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Jo Becker, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Ginni Thomas Texts Expose Rift in House Jan. 6 Panel
description: There is debate within the committee investigating the assault on the Capitol over whether to seek testimony from the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas about her efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: WASHINGTON — Buried in the thousands of documents that Mark Meadows, former President Donald J. Trump’s final White House chief of staff, turned over late last year to the House committee examining the Jan. 6 attack were text messages that presented the panel with a political land mine: what to do about Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Brooke
title: The Funny Woman’s Stylist
description: Rebecca Grice has cultivated a clientele of “S.N.L.” actors and musicians who share her inclination toward unusual, and unusually comfortable, clothes.
content: Of all the places a person might feel at home in her clothes, the Academy Awards does not immediately come to mind. The Oscars are the pinnacle of celebrity theater, with attendees buffed to superhuman levels of glamour and sheathed in couture gowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Descendants Trace Histories Linked by Slavery
description: Some American descendants of enslaved people and others whose ancestors profited are using online portals to collaborate and reckon with their shared family pasts.
content: Each week, Sharon Morgan sits at her desk and consults property records, deeds and wills that draw a clear line from her computer in Noxubee County, Miss., to her ancestors who were enslaved at a nearby plantation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Real Justice: Justice Jackson
description: From Anita Hill to Ketanji Brown Jackson, the Senate keeps embarrassing itself.
content: WASHINGTON — A snarling pack of white male Republicans ripping apart a poised, brainy Black woman at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, using sordid innuendos and baseless claims about race and porn to smear her, as her pained family sits behind her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
title: Late Surge Has Fiery French Leftist Eyeing Presidential Runoff
description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, a skilled orator and veteran politician, hopes to become the first left-wing candidate since 2012 to reach the second round of France’s presidential election.
content: LE HAVRE, France — Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the leading left-wing candidate in France’s upcoming presidential election, once likened himself to one of nature’s slowest animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Bennett
title: The Shame Industrial Complex Is Booming. Who’s Cashing In?
description: In “The Shame Machine,” the data scientist Cathy O’Neil seeks to discover who exactly has a vested interest in our unhappiness.
content: THE SHAME MACHINEWho Profits in the New Age of HumiliationBy Cathy O’Neil with Stephen Baker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn Chan
title: How to Game the Dystopian Future
description: In “Imaginable,” the futurist and game designer Jane McGonigal argues that being open to even far-fetched catastrophes can better prepare us.
content: IMAGINABLEHow to See the Future Coming and Feel Ready for Anything ― Even Things That Seem Impossible TodayBy Jane McGonigal
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Hotelier’s Post Barring Native Americans Prompts Outrage in South Dakota
description: The comments by Connie Uhre, 76, led to a protest, widespread condemnation by city leaders and a federal civil rights lawsuit.
content: A recent social media post by a hotel owner in Rapid City, S.D., announcing that Native Americans would be barred from the business after a shooting in one of the hotel’s rooms has prompted swift condemnation from community leaders, a protest and a federal civil rights lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel and Jason Karaian
title: Who’s Buying Russian Stocks?
description: Trading has resumed after the market closed for a month, but it’s not business as usual.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Katie Glueck and Dana Rubinstein
title: Adams Says Encampments of Homeless People Will Be Cleared
description: Mayor Eric Adams said his administration was pursuing a citywide effort to remove hundreds of makeshift campsites from streets and parks.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said on Friday that his administration was pursuing plans to clear New York City’s streets of makeshift campsites where homeless people live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hayley Phelan
title: The Insidious Effects of the Meme-ification of War
description: The juxtaposition of images of a war with celebrities and pet videos in a social media feed is disturbing. It’s also desensitizing.
content: Last week, as heavy bombardment rocked Ukrainian cities, killing at least hundreds of civilians and sending millions more fleeing, Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, the man behind the vicious attacks, was challenged to a duel by the billionaire Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Plea Negotiations in Sept. 11 Case Go on Hiatus for Ramadan
description: Hearings in the death penalty case are scheduled for May but could be postponed because one defendant needs a new lawyer.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Prosecutors and defense lawyers returned to the United States on Saturday from a first round of plea bargain talks that focused on how the five men who are accused of helping to plot the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, would serve out sentences in U.S. military custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: UConn’s Incredible Streak Is at Stake
description: A game on Saturday could end one of the most celebrated streaks in sports: Connecticut’s 13 straight Final Four berths.
content: A game on Saturday could end one of the most celebrated streaks in sports: Connecticut’s 13 straight Final Four berths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Several Explosions Heard in Western Ukraine, Near Polish Border
description: Fire and smoke were visible after several explosions were heard in central Lviv, in western Ukraine, not far from Poland’s border.
content: Fire and smoke were visible after several explosions were heard in central Lviv, in western Ukraine, not far from Poland’s border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Ben Laffin and Benjamin Foley
title: A Desperate Escape From Mariupol
description: Ukrainian families are taking enormous risks to try to flee Mariupol, traveling through Russian checkpoints — and in some cases land mines — to try to get to safety.
content: Ukrainian families are taking enormous risks to try to flee Mariupol, traveling through Russian checkpoints — and in some cases land mines — to try to get to safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Australian Marine Conservation Society
title: Mass Bleaching Event Hits Australia’s Great Barrier Reef
description: This year’s mass bleaching marked a disturbing first as it occurred during a La Niña climate pattern, when more rain and cooler temperatures typically provide a moment of respite for sensitive corals to recover.
content: This year’s mass bleaching marked a disturbing first as it occurred during a La Niña climate pattern, when more rain and cooler temperatures typically provide a moment of respite for sensitive corals to recover.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Free Speech Endangered?
description: First of a two-part series: Readers discuss “cancel culture,” civility and the First Amendment, in response to an editorial. Next: Speech and self-censorship on campus.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 26, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 26, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about the Supreme Court confirmation hearing of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson misstated the role of Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky. He is Senate the minority leader, not the majority leader.
source.name: The New York Times
